detailed_caption:
The image is a flowchart that shows the process of a Med3DVLM model. It is divided into two sections. 

On the left side of the image, there is a diagram that explains the different stages of the model. The first stage is labeled "Contrastive Training" and shows a cross-sectional view of a patient's brain. The second stage is titled "Text Encoder (Clinical)". The diagram shows a table with three columns and three rows. The table is labeled with the names of the stages.

The first column is labeled as "Vision Encoder" and has a red arrow pointing to it, indicating the direction of the flow of data. The third column is labelled as "Multimodal Projector (MLP-Mixer)" and has an orange arrow pointing towards it. The fourth column has a blue arrow pointing down to the next stage, indicating that the model is being used to generate a medical report based on this image. The fifth column has the model number "LLM with LORA" and a label that reads "Multimedia Projector".

Overall, the image shows how the model works and how it works.

The image is a diagram that shows the multi-modal projector based on multi-scale MLP-Mixer. It consists of two layers, one labeled "Mixer Layer x N" and the other labeled "Spatial". 

There are two layers in the diagram, labeled "Low Features" and "High Features". The layers are connected to each other by a series of wires. The wires are arranged in a grid-like pattern, with each layer representing a different component of the project.

The first layer on the left side of the diagram is labeled "SPatial" and has a label that reads "SPATIAL". The second layer is labelled "Full Connected". The third layer is marked "GELU". The fourth layer is called "Output".

Overall, the diagram shows how a multi-mode projector is based on multiple-scale MLP-Mixers.

detailed_caption:
The image is a black and white MRI scan of the cervical spine. The scan is divided into two sections, with the left side showing the left and right side of the image. The left side shows the spinal cord and spinal cord, while the right side shows a normal MRI spinal cord.

The image also includes text that explains the technique of the scan, which explains that the vertebral bodies and discs are of normal height and signal with no malignant. The posterior elements are normal, which are not visible in the image, but they are not clearly visible. The image also mentions that the normal MRI cervical spine is widely patent. The parabencial soft tissues are normal.
extracted_text: Technique:Sagittal T1, T2 and TIRM weighted imaging was obtained through the cervical spine as well as axial T1 and T2images. Oblique T2 weighted images were acquired through the neural exit foramina bilateralally.Findings:· The vertebral bodies and discs are of normal height and signal with no malignment. The posterior elements arenormal.· No disc bulges are identified.· The cranial-cervical junction is unremarkable, as is the spinal canal and cord.. The neural exit formamina are widely patent. The paraveterbral soft tissues are normal.Conclusion:Drology.comNormal MRI cervical spine.
